title: parrot.txt
docSource: a text file uploaded by the user.
pageContent:
Overview
--------
Parrots are colorful, intelligent birds belonging to the family Psittacidae, which includes over 400 species such as macaws, cockatoos, parakeets, and lovebirds. They are found mainly in tropical and subtropical regions around the world.

Physical Characteristics
------------------------
- Size: Parrots range greatly in size—from the tiny 8 cm (3 inch) pygmy parrot to the large 1 m (3.3 feet) hyacinth macaw.
- Plumage: Their feathers come in vibrant colors such as green, red, blue, and yellow, often in striking combinations.
- Beak: Parrots have strong, curved beaks adapted for cracking nuts and seeds.
- Feet: They have zygodactyl feet—two toes pointing forward and two backward—helping them grasp branches and food.

Behavior and Temperament
------------------------
- Parrots are social birds that live in flocks in the wild.
- They are known for their intelligence and ability to mimic human speech and sounds.
- They communicate using vocalizations, body language, and displays of feathers.
- Parrots are playful and curious, often requiring stimulation and social interaction to remain happy.

Diet and Habitat
----------------
- Parrots are primarily herbivores, feeding on seeds, nuts, fruit, nectar, and occasionally insects.
- They inhabit a range of environments, including rainforests, savannas, and coastal mangroves.
- Some species, like the kea of New Zealand, live in mountainous regions.

Uses by Humans
---------------
- Parrots are popular as pets due to their colorful appearance and vocal abilities.
- They play roles in ecotourism and are culturally significant in many societies.
- However, the pet trade and habitat destruction have endangered many wild species.

Reproduction
-------------
- Most parrots nest in tree cavities or cliffs.
- Females typically lay between 2–8 eggs, depending on the species.
- Both parents often care for the young, which are born blind and featherless.

Fun Facts
---------
- The African grey parrot is one of the most intelligent birds, capable of understanding words and concepts.
- Parrots can live for a very long time—some macaws over 70 years!
- They use their beaks not just for eating, but also for climbing and playing.
